reviewText: If you've got a few mates and think you’d enjoy some friendly banter over a fun, sports-strategy game then Blood Bowl 2 is fantastic. It’s a pretty accurate digital version of the great board game launch way back when and if you learn to laugh at your misfortune and you’ll enjoy it even more (the game has a habit of seeming to deliberately undo your best laid plans with unlucky dice rolls, lol).\nThe campaign is simple, but a good intro to the mechanics of the game. Treat it as an extended tutorial rather than the main feature of the game. The AI customisable single-player leagues are decent, but the AI isn’t sophisticated enough to try those desperate plays in the late stages of the game, and thus becomes a bit predictable.\nThe multiplayer is where the real fun is to be had. There are a bunch of leagues you can enter and the community is normally made up of decent people (as with any game you’ll find the sore losers and those that just constantly complain about their “bad” luck… but for the most part people are friendly). If you can get enough mates together then private leagues offer endless enjoyment (and bragging rights)

reviewText: Blood Bowl 2 is a game that wants to celebrate the nostalgia of the original tabletop version, while also offering players a little something new to go along with it. The aim of the game is pretty simple, players need to score the most Touchdowns!! Of course, it’s not as simple as that however, as there are increasingly-difficult teams standing in your way. Timing your run as well as creating the right situation to give your team the advantage, all while a timer is counting down, is crucial to whether or not you end up scoring those Touchdowns!! And lest not forget the repetitive failed dice rolls, which will be something that people will hate.\n\nThat being said, the game looks great and plays well. I do recommend it to anyone, so long as you have a little patience and a handle on your temper, failed dice rolls will make you scream at your monitor.

reviewText:
For someone unfamailair with the franchise; it's a turnbased, tactical, quasi-football simulation with rpg and progression mechanics using the warhammer universe.  Kind of a mouthful right?  It works suprisingly well though.

This game is almost less of a sequal than a graphics and UI overhaul of the first game.  The game itself is functionally identical in terms of gameplay, but all the peripheral portions have been improved.  The UI is now easy to use and mostly intuitive (if you assume that should just be a given, play the first game and weep).  The graphics are not just functional as they were in the original, but actually quite good with cutscenes showing the action and giving a visceral thrill when your minotaur curb stomps a dwarf.  Full game pad support.  The team manager has more depth and it's now easy to almost instantly create custom leagues to play in.  You also now have the ability to trade your players online to other people which is just an interesting feature.

One of the largest improvements is the addition of an actual tutorial in the form of the campaign.  It's a little slow but actually tells you what does what as opposed to the original blood bowls method of, Just click around and hope for the best."  The campaigns narrative is also charmingly silly which is a plus.

Given the longevity of the previous game the community is going to be extremely active for some time as well

reviewText:
As a long time player of tabletop games related to this genre, I was drawn into this game by some fun videos on YouTube.

I wish the general community was as fun as the people who play on YouTube...

Pros - GW has a real knack for a sort of gallows humor and tongue in cheek style that somehow manages to be both dark and silly at the same time. It lends itself well to games that actually grew out of war simulations. The two narrators are entertaining, as GW characters are wont to be, and Cyanide I feel did a wonderful job capturing the flavor of the game.

Cons -

1. The UI is clunky. There is no entirely safe way to plan your moves. Misclicks result in anything from having to start all over to having your player throw the ball across the field when you did not intend it.

2. The teams are not particularly well balanced. This goes back to it being a GW game. GW, for those of you now aware, stands for Games Workshop. This is a company that just abandoned a decades old wargame franchise seemingly specifically to spite a sector of their customer base they apparently considered harmful for their sales.

We'll see how that works out. Meantime, Blood Bowl 2 sports a handful of the teams available in the semi-official (I.E. not at all supported by GW for decades now) tabletop rules. Skaven are all but unplayable. Chaos seem to rule the leagues based on the fact that they have access to an entirely separate set of upgrades that other races can only rarely access (mutations). Skaven can get them fairly easily too, but Skaven die in higher levels in truckloads with an armor value of 7 even on front line players. As the game rewards survival of multiple games heavily, Skaven and other low armor, high finesse teams find it hard to compete at higher levels of play. At least one private league now invites ONLY finesse teams into its league to avoid the devestation the high armor and high strength teams visit on their weaker cousins.

There is no cure for this imbalance in sight. My experience with GW - players and designers alike - is that making the game balanced and competative is not really high on their list of things to do. Wonder if Cyanide can break that trend? So far, the answer is no.

3. The graphics are pathetic. This game offered little in the way of graphics to begin with. It is a standard sort of top down view with very clunky camera control. But to make matters worse, players move about stiffly, often ending up somewhere other than where you aimed them only to slip into place like a loose block, and the handful of full screen animations that pop up typically sport part of one player poking through the other player because of bad positioning of the camera and/or models during the animation render.

At one point the game reversed the team uniforms between my Skaven and the opposing Skaven team...?

In short, just old fashioned sloppy graphics and animation work.

4. The community is not nearly as friendly as the YouTube videos that seem to be the main marketing arm for the game would lead you to think.

Summary: Nice idea, but the execution is predictably pathetic as GW tends to just pawn its IP off to whoever is willing to fork over the money and let the chips fall where they may. There has never in the history of GW been anything remotely resembling quality control as far as their game rules go. They make wonderful miniatures and great game fluff, but horribly horrible games. And their company is quite obviously struggling because of it.

In any event, I would definitely not recommend this game. The lack of balance between the teams and the clunky UI have left me entirely uninterested in continuing play, and like so many GW fans, the player base seems to be a bunch of rabid dogs whose main function in life is to convince people to play games with them by treating them like crap and pretending there's nothing wrong with the game's design or execution.

Caveat - There are those who accuse me of being Sausage fingered". I seem to do well enough in pretty much every other video game I play though. I'm pretty sure this is just the typical GW fanboy reaction to anything negative you ever say about their games

reviewText:
The game, while tactically very fun, is slow; opponent AI turns take between 1 and 2.5 minutes; end result is that I find something else to do while my (AI) opponent takes its turn.

But that doesn't make it a bad game, it just makes it a slow game. The negative recommendation is related to saving.

1. You cannot save in the middle of a match. Period. Combine that with the aforementioned slowness of the game (call it 4 minute rounds, and 16 rounds in a match), and you're looking at losing up to an hour of gameplay if you have to leave before the end.
2. Having just played an aforementioned hour-long match (which I enjoyed very much!), the game simply did not record the progress. I was taken back to the Solo League screen, with the same opponent I had just played, and none of the gained stats.

Such a simple concept should not be simply not allowed (saving a game), nor should it straight up fail to save progress in the rare instance that your progress is recorded. That's pretty silly.

reviewText:
Well as a huge fan of of the original game it saddens me to not be able to reccomend BB2.

Pros:
Graphically much improved from the first game.
Entertaining dialogues in the career mode even if it is over in a blink.
Cons:
Game is hard for the wrong reasons. The first one was hard because you were taking a bloody 900 rated team and bashing it into a 1200 rated team. This game is hard because you take your 1400 rated team and play a 1000 rated team and you watch as every.single. roll. goes thier way. I'm all for RNG and it adds a lot of complexity to the gameplay but whatever bonus there is to the ai rolls is absolutely infuriating at times.
Its annoying to watch as your player gets tripped twice and you waste a re-roll, and then have the ai Magically move 6 players with no problem with a 33% chance or lower each move. To me this kills the original base for playing the game. Whats the point of spending time strategizing how to protect the carrier when the 1 opponant who magically gets by the 4 defenders ko's him and when i have the ai carrier completely surrounded, lone behold its like 50/50 if he actually goes down.
There is an astounding lack of content for the price.
Customization is at an all time low. Individual player customizations are only a handful and team customization is almost non existent. What could be considered customization" is procedural stadium upgrades and additional dlc.


If this title was 15$ I would say yeah give it a go

reviewText:
Blood Bowl 2 is still relatively poor content wise in comparison with previous installments, but even with a small roster of teams and a lack of visual variety (character faces, cheerleaders etc) it can still give you many hours of good fun.

The original board game is compelling. Frustrating at times but not as unfair as some make it sound. It's so nice to have the computer make all the calculations for you and present them in what I find a pretty clear way. The UI could probably be improved but I find it very efficient already.

The campaign is quite fun (even though it's for human/empire team only)  and a good intro to the game mechanics. The AI is pretty good though it's probably better to play that kind of games against other people.

A solid game with a not so bad model : it seems that if you buy the game now, you'll get many future pieces of DLC for free.

I recommend it

reviewText:
The game isn't BAD. But it's not Blood Bowl. Not in the shape that Blood Bowl players of decades know as Blood Bowl.
Cyanide has made their own little uneccesary changes, because they know better than the rest of us. Thus creating a Blood Bowl that is gorgeous to look at, but it's not the Blood Bowl most players recognize.
Not only have they done this, but they've done this without ever ONCE trying to explain WHY they do these things. Nor do they offer the ordinary fan an option to play with the standard rules of the game.
So.. I regret having given my money to Cyanide for this 'almost but not quite BB' game.

reviewText:
Great game.

This coming from a veteran of the tabletop game, stretching back to the 1st and 2nd editions in the 80s.

Played plenty of Chaos Edition, but much prefer this version. Amongst other things, it feels more epic. Thankfully we no longer have to play matches In an empty field or on a stupid boat!

Also, I can get a random match always within seconds. True, the open league has its own issues, but that's another conversation entirely. With Chaos Edition I would have to set the matchmaker going and go off and do something else instead. More often than not it wouldn't even find me an opponent. Really frustrating.

Sure, BB2 isn't  perfect. It needs more races, especially to keep the Chaos teams a bit more under control. Thankfully the new teams that are on their way should do that. Personally, all my favorite  teams are already in the game (apart from maybe Norse), so I can't really complain.

Would like to see race/specific cheerleaders, and some variation on the crowd members when a player is surfed.

Would also like to see player models develop as players earn levels. That was a nice touch in Chaos Edition.

Overall, buy this game. There is a strong community, particularly in private leagues and will only get stronger with the introduction of the upcoming new races, plus the World Cup of course.

reviewText:
Preface-
The Warhammer/40k franchise has always been a well-known staple of tabletop gaming. I am more of a D20 player, myself, but I've always admired Warhammer and its sheer level of depth despite the mechanical simplicity. I love Games Workshop if for no other reason that they have a VAST library of video games within the Warhammer franchise. It's difficult to find players for tabletop matches, let alone be willing to teach/learn all of the mechanics and nuances of the variety of games. PC gaming, especially, opens the doors for AI battles and relative ease of access to real opponents. Bloodbowl, and other Warhammer games have given me a workaround to play against enthusiasts and novices alike without having to memorize too many new rules.

That said, if you're a Turn-based strategy player, you're already well aware of the potential heartbreak of RNG. And Bloodbowl 2 is no exception. There are moments where it's baffling how an opponent can dodge so effectively, even if the odds of failure are only 1/6. Times where clutch plays are thwarted by that dumbass rolling double 1's and dropping the ball.

The rules are very simple, and compared to the first Bloodbowl game, much more accessible and novice-friendly. The UI improvements are substantial and the graphics and audio are fun, and fitting. The announcers are great, and when they grow stale, the option to turn off the audio (or down) is available.

Despite simplicity, the depth of strategy is excellent. I truly didn't think, while playing the tutorial, that it could reach the level of complexity to keep me stumped during a turn. But risk/reward in this game feels very tangible, and the violent, dark-humor atmosphere is simply perfect.

I hope there will be future DLC or expansions that add additional customization options, however. They are pretty lackluster. And, to avoid aforementioned repetitive audio, record additional announcer voiceovers. Perhaps even a variety of announcers.

TL:DR:

Fun. Great audio. (Needs a decent sountrack). Strategy layer and UI exceptional.

reviewText:
The community has a lot of mixed feelings about this one, and I can see why. It does feel kind of unfinished compared to BB1, but at the same time it has a number of great improvements imho. It's still blood bowl and it looks great, plus the ui is much improved for those who are new to the bitter kisses of nuffle. I personally think that it is worth the purchase, but it may take awhile for it to feel like a fully polished blood bowl game. I personally have faith that the developers will pull it off, though. Their decision to release 4 teams for free really boosted my opinion of them as well.

I give this one a cautious recommendation.

8/10

reviewText:
Blood Bowl 1 has been one of my favourite games to play with a friend. It's only flaw was the lack of multiplay in season mode. So I've been waiting anxiously for BB2. Now that I've played it for about 60 hours, I have a mixed feeling with it.

The game is basically Blood Bowl 1 with updated graphics and multiplay. That isn't a bad thing. BB1 already had everything in place. First complaint comes from single player campaign, as you can play it only with human team. After playing through the campaign, I started coaching my own team online. And there was the games' major problem. I had bought the game and both DLC teams, so I knew the team options are going to be limited. In fact, it almost crippled the whole game. I really miss the Norse or Amazon teams, as those were my favourite in BB1. Also, knowing that I have to pay even more in future to get more teams pisses me off.

If you liked BB1 as a game, youre gonna like BB2 also. So ask yourself which is more important to you:

1) Lots of different teams to choose from, but multiplaying only as hotseat
or
2) Improved graphics and possibility to play online, but (very) limited selection, of different races/teams

If you chose option 1, I suggest you continue playing BB1 and wait BB2 discount offer . If you chose option 2 and don't mind paying extra for more teams, go ahead and buy this game.

*If you are an experienced Blood Bowl player, you may want to add me.. ;)

reviewText:
This key was obtained from evolve.pr for purposes of review

Summary:
Blood Bowl 2 is an odd one. There's definitely a bunch of fun to be had with friends here: from a pure strategy level, the game does bring the challenge in several ways in a back and forth chess match. The game has definitely been improved from the original, as the UI implementation has made a lot of necessary changes to make the game more accessible to the average gamer. But the game's core design has a couple of things that will cause massive frustration for players, as a lack of customization in leagues, options that seem to be missing, and the dreaded RNG element of the game will drag the game down while it's attempting to take off. This game hits a niche for strategy elements that's for sure, and sadly, I can recommend it as a sale title for the general public, but a good title to have for strategy enthusiasts who like the subject matter, and people who are willing to take a hit or two while playing through the game's randomization element.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KDlA9ie3oY0

Lists:

+:
On a pure strategy level, the game works in a chess like manner very, very well. Two coaches going at it on an intellectual level will really turn it into a battle of wits.
The game feels a bit balanced in terms of overall aggressive/defensive gameplay, and that several strategies will be viable.
UI vastly improved from Blood Bowl 1. Lot easier to see what's going on and what your options are. A lot easier to see exactly what is going on then in the previous game.
Different classes play reasonably and give you a reason to try them all to see what works for you. While races may play similarly, you can really get deep into the customization of your team through varies of ways in player progression.
Punishes for staying in the endzone and sidelines, good design in making them punishing places to be.
Skill system can take away the RNG element a bit and really adds a level of depth to the game.
Campaign eases you into the mechanics of the game, and despite some confusion caused because of the changing concepts, it did the job reasonably well.
The announcers stand out, especially in the campaign mode. Good situational humor and the two voice actors do a fantastic job of bringing them to life.
Character models look good, especially with mutation system to make characters stand out on the field.
-:
The game's RNG is brutal, to the point where those who dislike random elements in games will find themselves screaming at the dice. Percentages may be misleading, as in real play it seems like there's differences from what is listed.
Lack of customization for rules in leagues, and the ability to tweak matches so that both sides play a game that they'd prefer over the basic rule set. Really need to emphasize this: this could have gone a long way to taking away the grievances that I had.
Lack of options. Games can feel really really slow, and really wanted a way to speed them up. While I appreciate a couple of the camera/UI options added, overall the game feels bare on the PC options as a whole.
Progression system really feels like a grind at times. To make your team the way you want, expect to grind a bit, and even more when they eventually die or retire.
Sometimes it isn't clear why a skill didn't work, even though at the bottom of the screen, you can see why.
Audio Lines get repetitive over time, it needed more variety here to take advantage of the improved presentation and great voice acting.
Clipping issues unfortunately pop up several times in close ups, and can make the technical precision of the game stand out in a bad way.
Under the hood (when slowed down or stuttering), you can see some corners cut on animation.
Wished mouse input when using windowed mode did not register clicks outside the context of the  window.
A couple of graphical bugs would show up from time to time.

reviewText:
Fun game with stability issues

While the game is very entertaining, and a big improvement over the previous verison, sadly it is extremely unstable. I have finished the last match of the campaign 4 times now, and every time it crashed during a cut scene. Sometimes the game just becomes so slow it is unusable - only restarting the game solves this. Saving games is hit and miss, sometimes it works, some times you have to start again. And sometimes it randomly crashes. This is with recent game and video drivers, and on supported OS and hardware.

I would recommend not getting the game now, but wait till they fix these problems.

reviewText:
I can't speak for the single player experience, as I only play multiplayer.

I started on Blood Bowl Chaos: Chaos Edition and this game is certainly a worthy successor in that regard.  The only hugely significant edge that Chaos edition has is that it has more races (specifically the most of the lower tier races).  While Blood Bowl 2 doesn't have all the races, it has most of the higher tier races and still enough variety that I haven't played through all of them yet myself.  Here are some of the things that I appreciate that may not be obvious from seeing the trailers and screenshots.

1.  The ability to rewind, pause, and skip in replays.
2.  When spectating a live game you don't need to fast forward to get to the current turn.
3.  The ability reconnect in a game in the case of a crash or a disconnect.
4.  Proper implementation of rolls like break tackle
5.  Option to use of dodge when being pushed to the sideline (though not available in the case of One turn touchdowns)

Some things that I would like to see.

1.  Fend as an optional skill when blocked with frenzy so you can frenzy trap.
2.  Grab as an optional skill so you can still surf with a grab player.
3.  New DLC races on a more frequent basis.  The current rate they are getting released is fairly slow.

reviewText:
This game is being left for dead, back to the old ways again.

I really, really want to LOVE this game.. and I think that goes for everyone else who's a long time BB fan. But it seems the developers/publishers are doing the best they can to make us all disappointed. It could be so damn great, but alas, always coming up very short.

Bucket list:
- No armour upgrades (building your team is a big deal, you want to love your team!)
- Some player animations look re-used from BB1
- All teams should have their own stadiums.
- No hall of fame screen for past or dead players - they just retire and never be seen again
- Team UI screens is horrible, lacking stats, looks thrown together by a developer.
- Cheerleaders are the same for everyone
- Lacking in team logos/team colors (why can’t we pick some colors, add a logo perhaps, more customization)
- Blood bowl is all about customization.. add as much of this as possible! silly hats, extra weapons, team colors/home ground advantages..
- Does not feel like a complete game without goblins and halflings.
- Adding pitch hazards to your games like the broken helicopter in the campaign
- dev’s excuses are not great, I think that after 2+ years of development this game would be so much further down the line.

If another developer had made this game, I would imagine that at launch the customization for teams and players would be huge. Almost too much!
You want to own the team and make it yours, not just another chaos team with black color like everyone else..

reviewText: 本人一直是blood bowl的忠实粉丝，这次出续作着实让我兴奋不已，拿到手开玩后发现确实比前代的画面和美工等方面高出不少，种族虽然不够前作丰富但也够玩了，经过我与其他玩家的讨论得出，此款游戏继承了前作的优点，具有很强的可玩性，但是有几点意见希望提供给开发组和其他玩家仅供参考：首先，球员生涯12个赛季就退役了，然而生涯的计算似乎不是以一个赛季为计算单位。其次，转会市场的功能解释不清楚，至今不知道转会市场的作用和使用方法。希望有大神解答。最后也是最令我跳槽的一点就是取消了一代球员服装随球员等级提高而变得更加华丽的设定，让高等级球员没有了独特的魅力，成就感大减。此游戏可玩性极高，自由度很大，因此予以推荐。

reviewText:
If you like turn based games, gridiron, violence and team management, get this game you will more then likely enjoy it.
I give this game a thumbs, up its a good solid game and it provides hours of fun.
May only have around 20 hours clocked up but ive only had it 3 days at the time of writing.

Is it worth full price ?

That is entirly up to the individual, there are a lot of people who feel this game is a cash grab. I personaly feel that on its release the price was a bit high but where the price settled is a good price.

Reason for purchasing the game.

I'm new to bloodbowl and I found playing the first game not easy to learn and the graphics were pretty poor, blood bowl 2's UI is easy to understand, and the models and characters are better then anything id be able to paint myself and look awesome.

I'd like to remark on some of the more negative posts.

Campaign just a tutorial:
This is true, but if any of the people complaining about this had played for more then 40 mins they would have found at match 9 thats %48 campaign completion its pretty much a normal solo league, with a story and the training wheels are fully off.

Campaign only for one race:
From memory campaign in blood bowl 1 was effectivly this games solo league so I dont see where the probem is.

DLC is a cash grab:
I don't see it this way, we get 8 races that are well fleshed out for a good price. $4 - $10 for a DLC team depending on what part of the world you live in, is a good price. Look at it this way you would never be able to buy and paint a blood bowl tabletop team for $10, just saying.

Graphics arent any better then the original:
The people who say this must be running the game on toasters, the game has been made on a brand new engine and is immensly better, easiest way to see this is pretty much looking at the steam pages for both.

Lesser issue, responding to artificial coach leveling:
This is why there will never be a local hotseat league mode with experiance for your coach, too many people would just cheat to level up their coach. a.k.a Artificial leveling making teams that only one person plays to just roll over and lose to your main team thus getting better exp for your coach.

reviewText:
Edit: Having looked through the other reviews, the vast majority of the negative reviews are from Blood Bowl fans who think the game is lacking features found in other formats, particularly BB:CE. This is fair, but completely glosses over the fact that Blood Bowl is an amazing game that has been going strong for over 20 years and is well represented in Blood Bowl 2. The missing features will come with time, but this is still a great way to play a great game.

--

I picked up the game in Jan 2016, and I belive it's been patched a few times since launch. I'm a BB fan from back in the day, and came to this after recently playing a few games on fumbbl. I was convinced after watching streamers play the Crendorian Invitational which makes for decent e-sports viewing.

This is a solid, intuitive and playable rendition of Blood Bowl. It's easy on beginners, building up the rules slowly, but caters to old hands by showing you the dice roll log (so you can see how many you missed by when your gutter runner trips over his own feet on the second go for it).

Upsides:
Looks fantastic
Made with a decent sense of humour
Easy for beginners
Good UI
Seems to have a solid league system and a decent player base on PC
Performance is good (I'm playing on a 2012 iMac using Bootcamp and it works flawlessly).
Downsides:
Single Player campaign built up to the full ruleset too slowly for me (as I know the rules)
Some deviations from the living rulebook, which is a shame
UI sometimes lets me down when I make unintentional dodges or GFI
Developers ran out of time and it seems they cut a lot of cosmetic details (e.g. all cheerleaders and fans are human)
Expensive especially when DLC is included

reviewText:
I usually don't write reviews, but I just have to help turn this wrong into right.

In short, it is a great and addictive game, but to trully enjoy it you need to invest some time into learning it and be Zen about RNG.


I would like to address some main negative review complaints:

- My dice were bad, the game is based on luck, no fun yadayadayada -

This is a hardcore unforgiving tactical strategy game with no save scumming option and RNG mechanics. You have to accept bad dice, they happen, and improve your gameplay so you dont have to roll a lot of dice at all.
Thats said, the game is not for everyone, but it is a matter of taste, not a game problem.

- Campaign and single player are boring/have issues, bugs -

This is a multiplayer game. End of the line. It gets fun and addictive when you play and win (or lose) agaunst a real person. Play online, single player and campaign are for learning the ropes.

- Multiplayer has bugs, crashes, etc -

There were some problems in the begginning, mostly fixed by now. You can also return to the game withing 6 minutes after the crash (most of the time anyway). I'd say there are no gamebreaking issues at the moment. Some problems might be related to your particular PC.

- Races as DLC! Price is too high -

Yeah, it kinda sucks. But hey it is 60% off as I am writing right now and for 10 bucks it is a steal. Races as DLC - not good, but atleast next 3 races are free and to be honest there are enough of them if you are new to the game.

- It is worse then BB1 -

Well, less races yeah, I agree. But it is visually better and more newbe-friendly. It does not exactly deserve negative review for that, imho

This is all I can think of at the moment, hope it helps.

See you on the pitch!

reviewText:
hmmmmmm... got some problems, seems to be re-accuring in the BB games and the reason i stopped playing the last game. just played a custom league against npc coaches, lotsa fun, some tough games in a knockout but then i get to the final, had 2 nights of great fun up to now.... i fail every role, my team gets knocked down every turn, i had 3 injurys by turn 2 and my best blitzer dead and 2 other players KO'd in the next turn, even after re-rolling the death it came up death, now if youve not played the BB table table game then this might seem resonable but if you have then you would know that in order to get a death twice in a row thats like 6 6's on a D6 in a row, oh and busting there armour twice, yes that can happen but in a game where i loose every role it seems weird. also i spent 3 turns atempting to pickup a ball, in fair weather , with an agi 4 player with safe hands and he shook the ball around like a tool before being flattened and the npc scoring.
Now this used to happen all the time in BB1 because it was a cheap to make game and i was hoping that the difficulty level in BB2 would be defined by coach skill and player abilities not by the blatant and almost obvious dice swindling. several of my mates have flat refused to buy this game because they knew it would be this way.
Dont really care about the price, the lack of teams, the medicore UI but really, this level of shoddy development is just poor.

I really wish i could get my money back for this game and am currently trying. if this was your problem with the first game then DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

reviewText:
Haven't tackled multi-player yet, and I'm really enjoying the game (Updated)

Enjoyed the campaign since I'm new to the series and it's a tutorial on the game.   I very much recommend the game as I venture into multi-player.  No it's not balanced, and yes it has random rolls but it is very strategic.

They will add teams over time and correct the few bugs in the game.

For those of you that despise the RNG of the game.  Great games such as backgammon do have a random element, and is the best comparison rather than a game of chess where a superior oponent will always beat an unskilled one.  I do think there is surprising depth so you 'mitigate' those chances of failure so that you stand a very good chance of beating an unskilled oponent.  Some teams do match up poorly versus others as in real football (which this is clarly 'NOT').  If you don't enjoy randomness in the game, this isn't for you.  After 100 hours I'm starting to learn that the ruleset is more complex than I first thought, and I keep learning to improve my game.  It soes suck to play better than an opponent, and suffer bad luck-- but sometimes you do get lucky at the last second to win and tie versus an opponent much better than you.  Over time, it does even out.  Although not for everyone, this is a great turn based strategy game best played against other players.  As a side note, each race is distinct and plays differently which adds replayability to the game.

I'm now an avid fan.

reviewText:
I'm going to start this review by admitting that I never played the original Blood Bowl. I own it, and I always wanted to like it, but the seeming overcomplexity of the system kept me from ever getting into it.

Blood Bowl 2 was pretty much the perfect game for me. The UI is clean, simple and easy to understand. The games are pegged at a nice length (usually around 40 minutes for me) and the solo league experience provides enough of a challenge for me as a new blood bowl player to be entirely engrossing. There are a large number of teams (currently eight), though hardcore blood bowl fans will probably be disappointed by the selection. More will almost certainly be released as DLC, but at the $45 price point that's frankly to be expected.

TLDR: If you're interested in a turn based strategy game with a fantasy sports twist this is certainly a game for you. If you're on the fence, or if you're a hardcore blood bowl fan you're probably better served waiting for a sale.

reviewText: Turn Based Arena Football With Fantasy Races and RNG\nBlood Bowl 2 is one of the best games I have played in a while. I think we can all agree that running around a football field with teams full of fantasy races bashing each other while trying to score touchdowns is simply an awesome premise. The game is turn based, which I love, and it involves quite a bit of dice rolling, which makes each match unique and unpredictable. The turnover" mechanic is brilliant. If you fail an action during your turn and one of your players gets knocked over
date: then your turn immediately ends.This leads to nailbiting choices like: "Yes
recommended: if I make this risky block
hoursPlayed: I'll score a touchdown. But if my player falls over instead
voteText: then my opponent will be in a good position to score. Do I wait for a better opportunity next turn? Or do I go for it now?"\n\nStrategyThere is real strategy to be had here. Manage your odds. Do everything that is safe first in case your rolls go south and end your turn. Learn how to set up block strings and use the all-important once-per-turn "blitz" move. Don't make unnecessary dice rolls. Your strategy will also vary greatly depending on which race you choose to play. Dwarves? Bash up your opponent's players and watch as they are carried off the field on stretchers. High Elves? Look for tiny openings in your opponent's defense and exploit them with your high agility
helpfulPercent: speed
votesHelpful:
and passing skills.

GraphicsThe art direction and graphics are first rate. I don't think I'll ever get tired of seeing my ogre (I named him "Slurple") smack down the opposing players. I still laugh out loud when someone fails a "Go For It" roll and goes tumbling to the ground and fumbles the ball. The prat falls and the accompanying sound effects are *perfect*. The person who designed this really knows their stuff.

The two commentators in the game (Bob and Jim) make me chuckle as well. When my ogre is lying prone on the ground
votesTotal: tries to get up
votesFunny: but misses his "intelligence" roll and goes nowhere
commentsCount: then one of the announcers might claim "I've seen *mushrooms* that look smarter than that."\n\nStabilityThe game is rock solid stable. I have not seen even one crash or freeze up during the 63+ hours I have been playing. I did encounter two bugs involving player lineups and gold inducements
column16: but these were fixed very quickly.\n\nIn the future
column17: I think I would like to see more robust league creation options
column18: as well as an easier way to see what skills players have on the field. The negative reviews I have read are written either by veterans of Blood Bowl 1 who dislike the fact that some of their favorite features are not in the game
column19: by people who do not understand how randomness works
column20: or by people who feel the game is too expensive. Note that there will be additional teams added to the game
column21: but you will need to purchase them at about $7 each if you would like to play as them. The base game comes with eight teams.\n\nIn any case
column22:
I am very happy with my purchase and would highly recommend Blood Bowl 2 to anyone who might enjoy turn-based strategy with RNG meshed with football in a high fantasy world.

Please follow this link if you are a new player and would like to read some helpful guides:

http://forum.bloodbowl-game.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=5500"

reviewText:
Hi Folks.

To everyone new to the Blood Bowl Franchise: this is not meant to be a Single Player Game.
All about the spirit and the fun comes from fighting other Players, its all about Strategy, Tactic and a bit of Luck some times. ( Its a Dice Game after all)

But first things first - Is BB2 better than BB1?

Kind of, yes. BB2 has a much better look all over the place, the UI is more Userfriendly, the presentation of the stadiums and the teams is awesome, it plays smoother and is just more enjoyable than BB1.

And there are so cool details they added, for example if you purchase a Bloodweiser Stand for your Stadium, the crowd is much more pushed and the sound effects of your fans cheering changes aswell, more singing and Vuvuselas all over the place, nice!

The graphics are great, with cool beating animations and close up cameras if something important happens, really cool and it delivers a nice feeling of being close to the Action.

So the Game itself, the Programming and Graphics are much better than BB1.

The most common reason for negative reviews is the lack of Content it has at the Moment.
And that in fact is true, BB1 has much more Content to deliver, but you need to consider that BB1 already has 2 Addons, and compared to the Base Game the Content is the same.

A few not gamebreaking but important things missing aswell, and hopfully will be added soon.
The Game lacks in case of Informations, for example no Hall of Fame for your Team, no Player Statistics, no information about Opposing Team pre Match, no Visual change of high lvl Players and so on.

In my opinion it seems they just where running out of time to implement all those things before release, and im very confident that they will add that kind of things the next few Months.

Additional Teams will be delivered saperatly as a DLC for 6,99$ each as far is i know, what is a fair price because the teams are really looking awesome.

So for everybody new to Bloodbowl, BB2 is the better choice. Because it has a better UI and a Singleplayer Campaign wich is in fact a large Tutorial.

To the Bloodbowl Veterans out there, you want to buy and play Bloodbowl 2 for the same reasons, you played BB1 instead of Fumble. If you want all the Content the BB Lore will offer and all the Statistics and information Possible, play Fumble, its free after all.
But if you want a nice looking Bloodbowl expirience that entertains you, just give BB2 a Chance.

reviewText:
I would like to start this review by saying one thing, if you are the type of gamer who hates games with dice rolling and gets angry when things don't go your way then DO NOT buy this game.  This game is very dice heavy and until you learn the rules and how to play properly you will make a lot of mistakes and end up blaming your losses on the dice rather than your own lack of knowledge of the games rules.  However if you like the idea of a complex dice based sports game and don't mind learning the rules then this is the edition to start with.

The main improvements this game has over the first Blood Bowl are the graphics and the UI, the original game was well known for its awful interface that left new players scared and confused while this one makes it much easier for new players to see the chances of success on things like dodges and ball pick ups.  And quite honestly that is all that this has over the original game, this isn't really that bad a thing as the UI was a serious issue but I feel like more could have been improved such as the multiplayer league system which now has less options that in the first game.

Other things I would like to see improved is the single player AI, in the first game it was woeful and to be honest it is no better in this version.  I have yet to lose a game against the AI and haven't even conceded a single touchdown against it yet.  While this may be good for newer players as it gives them a pretty much braindead AI to practice against it would have been nice to be able to have a challenging single player mode for once.  The multiplayer is still where the meat of the game is and it remains much the same although they have removed the MP lobby that you could use to chat with fellow players before your game and arrange matches etc.

The number of teams the game was released with is also a bone of contention for some players as it only has 8 plus the two you got from pre-ordering which is far, far less teams than Blood Bowl Chaos Edition has.  This will eventually sort itself out though as Cyanide have said they will be releasing teams as DLC, this is something I am fine with as long as they pricing of said DLC isn't over the top but I know some people hate DLC so much that it ruins games for them so I thought I should mention it.  However the teams the game comes with should be plenty to suit most players but I would have liked to have had the Undead team in there as part of the base races.

There are also still quite a few technical issues still with the game, it causes my graphics card to overheat and crashes the PC unless I use a frame limiter to limit myself to 30fps which I am not okay with and others have reported similar issues with the overheating in this game while other games run fine.  I have also experienced the black screen bug where your screen just goes black but the game is still running fine, you just can't see it.  As for the in game options menu, it is worfully inadequate, you cannot play in fullscreen at all only borderless windowed mode, which is pretty much the same but seems a bit of an oversight.  The graphics options are practically non existent as well, simply choosing from Low to Very High with no advanced options at all.  While I am sure that these things will be patched you may want to hold off for now if these sound like major issues for you.

I realise that this review reads quite negatively but I do truly enjoy this game and I think that in a few months time with patches and new races being added it will be the best version but it still doesn't quite edge out the first game yet as they have removed features we liked and added a few things that nobody asked for and some that just make it plain worse (player ageing in leagues?)  Honestly though if you are a brand new player who wants to get into Blood Bowl then buy this edition as it is far more user friendly and better looking to boot.  If you are already a seasoned Blood Bowl 1 coach though I would recommend holding fire until they have fixed the worst bugs and maybe added some more teams, though if you are playing for multiplayer you will probably have to buy it anyway since I expect it has already massively reduced the number of people playing the first!

reviewText:
Same deal as the first version of Blood Bowl 1, missing a bunch of features but still a fun game.


Tl;dr Do not buy it >>>YET<<< unless you're a diehard bloodbowl fan. It is completely unfinished and as buggy as the first iteration of Blood Bowl PC, and is a straight downgrade from chaos edition in a lot of ways aside from # of teams. That being said, it will almost certainly be improved a lot in the long-run, just as Blood Bowl 1 was, so if you don't buy it now get it after a few patches for sure, in a sale. It's just a shame they seem to have not learnt much from BB1.


The Bad:

- The league system has been downgraded heavily in choice of options for organizers in almost every way possible, there's no excuse for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the only thing that keeps people playing your game.
- Very buggy/some mechanics and skills just flat out do not function as intended (almost as bad as the first game).
- No grid still
- Hella expensive
- 8 teams and it's hella expensive for 8 teams, they're also very vanilla teams, none of the fun/abnormal ones.
- No aesthetic change on player level up anymore
- Chance of some dodgy things with Cyans (their in-game currency)
- Wave goodbye to cool and varied pitches.
- Game is literally unfinished, still no team specific cheerleaders, only two models in the crowd etc.
- Can't view opponents team during inducements anymore.
- Mouse click functions are reversed from the first game. Maddening.

The Good
- Good quality spectating, probably the absolute biggest upgrade.
- Bob and Jim are back, kinda.
- More new player/idiot friendly. It displays the end % chances for actions as well as the dice.
- It is prettier.
- The proposed DLC model for teams is better than expansions and offers far better choice (imo).
- Better UI (I hesitate to put this here, since the UI is def better in design, but they removed so many features from it to simplify it).
- Dark Elves look ridiculously more fruity.
- It's still Bloodbowl, and there's no substitute bug yet.
- Possiblity of some neat things with Cyans.
- You can access the options mid-match
- Lots of small quality of life changes.
- Praise the sun memes.

reviewText:
This game really is a blast if you're inclined for a little luck to be thrown in with your strategy. You're playing football in the Warhammer Fantasy universe with the races from Warhammer fantasy. Except you level and learn skills as you play through as the team manager making all the choices you want to influence the design of your team. Dice can be your friend or your enemy as you're playing the game so don't let it get to you if you get a few bad rolls because sometime soon you'll have amazing rolls.

We currently have 10 teams in the game which for some reason has people getting very upset because not every team was released out right. Saying Blood Bowl 1 has all the teams therefor 2 must as well. When Blood Bowl 1 came out it had 8 teams on release, 9 after a month and after a year the other teams were released. Give Blood Bowl 2 time, they'll put the rest of the teams in.

The game is absolutely worth a purchase and your time, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
First experience with video Blood Bowl, did not play 1. The game works exactly as intended, super fun AI games between those tabletop matches, plays great with a controller. More races would be nice, it's probably in the works, but the 8 races provided really cover most of the play styles. Friendly match with shared or two controllers is great for playing with a buddy and teaching someone how to play.

BUT the textures bug out sometimes? (Shadows of helmets appearing when the helmet is off, block status symbols showing up over and over in a line.) The graphics aren't BAD but they aren't good either. Commentary and bowler audio gets old quick. This game isn't polished. Campaign is a joke, play solo-league for good AI play and team management.

Overall recommend if what you want is the latest version of video Blood Bowl. If you want more races, I've heard good things about Blood Bowl 1 - Chaos Edition. Though I've heard the UI is rougher and it does not have native controller support. If you're unsure what Blood Bowl is, or aren't super excited to play it on a PC, I'd just wait the price out. It's hard to recommend the game at this price unless you really want to play.

reviewText:
Blood Bowl 2 has issues when compared to its predecessor, in a vacuum. It has 10 teams currently (Wood elves and Lizardmen just added) rather than 25, and it has a new price tag, of course, however, I feel this sells short what Blood Bowl 2 does well.

The AI has been dramatically improved, which is not thrilling for those who play in human only leagues, but for those of us that play against the AI, this is a big deal. Gone are the days of the AI, as its first action of the turn, trying to dodge through 12 tackle zones and go for it twice as a dwarf. Instead, it seems to do its turn in priority order, from most likely to work to least likely, and it seems to avoid doing bizarre and silly things unlikely to have effect. As elves, it steps out of block zones, forcing you to blitz if you are going to hit it, just like a human would.

Assuming the new races do not cost an arm and a leg, and come out at a fair clip, I think Blood Bowl 2 is going to be a great upgrade on its ancestor.

reviewText:
If you are after a perfect game then this game is probably not for you, not sure I have ever found a game that isn't riddled with flaws from someones point of view.   Game is not perfect by any stretch of the imagination and sort of has a feel of being slightly rushed and incomplete at the moment.  It is a great deal of fun none the less and if like me you grew up playing blood bowl on the tabletop it still feels right.  I will say make sure your focus is multiplayer however as the single player is more than a little bobbins, but if you are a true tabletop gamer what the hell are you playing single player for.....have a word with yourself :P

Dice rolls are still frustrating as they were in BB1 but then as someone that once rolled 19 1's out of 24 dice for armour saves on a 2+ with real dice sometimes you just have to smile. The dice gods are fickle and all that jazz!

I don't understand the rage about the races to be honest, the original blood bowl was released with 8 races and this is released with 8 races too with another 2 DLC races to be released soon.  Personally I have only ever played with Dark Elves, Chaos, Orcs and Undead since I was a kid so 3 out of 4 in the initial release I am happy with.  I would rather pay say a few quid for the DLC race I want rather than considerably more for a full expansion with 90% of the races I literally have no interest in.  Everyone will be different in this respect some people will want all the races because they feel incomplete otherwise.  I put that down to my background in the tabletop game, only ever brought, painted and played with teams I wanted to use, had no interest in owning every team, didn't have anywhere near enough money from school holiday jobs to afford them anyway.

Would I recommend this game to everyone?  NO

Would I recommend this to my friends that like me are tabletop gamers and love all this kind of stuff as fun and a bit of relaxation after work?  YES YES YES

reviewText:
Reason for Buying

1. Have the board game.
2. Played the first computer game.
3. Thought the graphics and team editing was cool.

Pros
Graphics - The game looks much better.
Game play is much better with better bells and whistles.
When you buy your team you can sell players if you need to change things around.  The last game you were stuck after buying the players.  Just remember that after you play a match, you can no longer sell that player for what you got it for.
Computer AI is way better than the last game.  I had a team knock one of my players out of the pitch.  Never happened in the old game unless I boxed myself in.

Cons

The fully editable teams is a lie.  WHY CAN'T I CHANGE THE PLAYERS NUMBER.  I play humans, love them.  So I want to have my lineman with 50-79, 90-99 numbers, my blitzers 20-49 numbers, catchers 80-89 numbers and throwers 1-19  numbers.
The number editor is a HUGE thing for me.  I know it sounds small but i was 100% getting the game for the option of changing numbers.
The start of the game and half time is a bit much.
I wish that knocking your opponent out of the pitch had the race of the person that knocked the other out of the pitch.  It's always humans.

I will play some more and add to this.

reviewText:
Blood Bowl 2, to put it simply: It's amazing.

An incredible improvement from Blood Bowl 1, simplified UI and upgraded graphics. This is a turn-based strategy-sports game that takes place on the Warhammer universe. You will play as the coach of teams of different races and duke it out on the pit on matches of Blood Bowl!

The upgraded graphics make the game feel epic every single moment, the animations are mind blowingly good, you'll see everything, from a Chaos Warrior dropkicking an Elf or a Dwarf beating a Minotaur to a pulp with his ale mug. To this add an action camera and slow motion as this is happening and you'll have epic fights every single time.

The added commentary of Jim and Bob will bring you some laughs until it starts getting repetitive, with this said, they do take a big part in the Single Player campaign mode which starts as a tutorial for the first couple of matches and then throws you right into a story mode.

On average a match will take about 60 minutes from start to finish so make sure that you have plenty of time before starting a game.

reviewText:
Terrific improvement over the original
nicer looking, smooth play,neat little extra's,such as your own stadium and upgrade ability for it.

Multiplayer,the imporatant part, works flawlessly with the exception of a couple of occasional bugs.
No deal breaker here,just annoying when they happen,but,should be remedied.

League management options are scarce at the moment but its obvious they are coming later.

Pre-order guys ended up getting both bonus teams as they were delayed a couple of days.good sports.

So,10 teams available is more than enough for now and more to come.

If you like playing H2H turn based games,this is great

Not Recommended if you are just after playing the AI or Single player,while its fine,its no comparison to playing a human opponent

Be Warned.......dummy spits and rage quitters are like locusts in this game,so find a good league to join and it will
minimize these goons.

8/10

reviewText: Great game and lots of fun. Could still use some UI tweaks and improvements to the AI leagues. And of course more races.
voteText: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First experience with video Blood Bowl, did not play 1. The game works exactly as intended, super fun AI games between those tabletop matches, plays great with a controller. More races would be nice, it's probably in the works, but the 8 races provided really cover most of the play styles. Friendly match with shared or two controllers is great for playing with a buddy and teaching someone how to play.

BUT the textures bug out sometimes? (Shadows of helmets appearing when the helmet is off, block status symbols showing up over and over in a line.) The graphics aren't BAD but they aren't good either. Commentary and bowler audio gets old quick. This game isn't polished. Campaign is a joke, play solo-league for good AI play and team management.

Overall recommend if what you want is the latest version of video Blood Bowl. If you want more races, I've heard good things about Blood Bowl 1 - Chaos Edition. Though I've heard the UI is rougher and it does not have native controller support. If you're unsure what Blood Bowl is, or aren't super excited to play it on a PC, I'd just wait the price out. It's hard to recommend the game at this price unless you really want to play.

reviewText: Blood Bowl is an incredible game where skill takes center stage but is also blended with gratuitous amounts of chaos, death and luck. This makes it entertaining because you can improve, ignore people who say BB is not skill based, while at the same time the chaos will always keep the game fresh as you just never know what will happen.\n\nCyanide's second implementation of the game is very solid. The graphics are wonderful and the UI is nice and clean. You may read about things that could be changed, however they are tweaks to an already great game.

reviewText:
I never played blood bowl before getting this game; so I have no experience with any other versions.

This game is very fun. It's a turned based football/rugby strategy game. The teams seem pretty different; some teams are good at the game itself, like ball handling/passing/catching, some try to kill/injure people to take an advantage, and some are a mixture of both.

I'm still new but there are a ton of talent points; so it looks like there is quite a bit of character customization. The game seems pretty deep; but it doesn't take too long to get the hang of the basics.

The visuals are pretty amazing for a turn based strategy. I can't think of one that looks better. The art style is also really cool.

The only thing I can really complain about is the camera, which you cannot spin.

Also the games can last an hour if both people take their time; and luck plays a huge factor in the game. These aren’t really bad things, but thing to be aware of.

So far I’m really liking this game, very fun 1v1 turn based strategy game.

reviewText:
Lock your doors and turn off your phones sports fans, it's time for Blood Bowl! The game that mashes American Football with Warhammer and ends up with comical results.

First up, I adore Blood Bowl so this review will be a bit biased.

Pros:-
UI has been polished up from the original title.
In game commentary is more entertaining.
Currently available teams are well balanced against each other.
Teams are persistent, no more rebuilding a team for each league you enter.
New Bretonnian team.
Cyan implimenation could be interesting if used purely for cosmetics as announced.

Cons:-
End Turn button located in an awkward area means you can sometimes misclick before you get used to it.
Selecting a player at the edge of the screen can sometimes be a chore due to the player information popups.
Single player campaign is a glorified tutorial.
No more multiplayer hotseat function.
Leagues have a tendency to be dominated by Clawpomb Chaos teams.
Only a handful of teams available at launch.
Two teams hidden behind a pre-order wall.

Yes, I know the con list is slightly larger than the pro list. However, most of the cons are minor issues to me and I will continue to rack up the hours on this game.

reviewText:
Blood Bowl 2, to put it simply: It's amazing.

An incredible improvement from Blood Bowl 1, simplified UI and upgraded graphics. This is a turn-based strategy-sports game that takes place on the Warhammer universe. You will play as the coach of teams of different races and duke it out on the pit on matches of Blood Bowl!

The upgraded graphics make the game feel epic every single moment, the animations are mind blowingly good, you'll see everything, from a Chaos Warrior dropkicking an Elf or a Dwarf beating a Minotaur to a pulp with his ale mug. To this add an action camera and slow motion as this is happening and you'll have epic fights every single time.

The added commentary of Jim and Bob will bring you some laughs until it starts getting repetitive, with this said, they do take a big part in the Single Player campaign mode which starts as a tutorial for the first couple of matches and then throws you right into a story mode.

On average a match will take about 60 minutes from start to finish so make sure that you have plenty of time before starting a game.

reviewText:
1st off i love warhammer, i play the table top, the video games, and read the books so im slighly bias.

BUT OFF THE TO REVIEW!

I was completely new to the blood bowl, and i heard it had a steep learning curve, so before i bought it i watched some gameplay vids to get an idea of the tactics. When i got the game i was shocked by how well the tutorial campaign is. They introduces you to the game bit by bit. 1st level there is no rolls, 2nd there are rolls but no turn overs, 3rd there are turn overs, 4th gives u all features but no injuries, etc. they gradually introduce u so its not all thrown at u at once. now once u  u get to the 5th level the campaign sucks because its no longer winning, its dumb objectives like, cripple 5 enemy players.....well that becomes a game of chance with dice rolls. BUT the game isnt about the capaign is about online.

Online is great, make your team, customize it (i would like more customizing features please), hire players and staff, etc. If a player dies hes gone for good, injured players can be out for a few games....it feels like running a real team. ITs also super smooth and all the teams strengths and weaknesses are clearly displayed.

over all i say its a good game but matches take at least an hour, so be prepared.

reviewText:
Worth the price if your not strapped for cash. Wish more nations were included (more coming in DLC).

At this point if your not 100% sold.... Wait for a sale. If you got some extra cash laying around, not a terrible place to put it. The enjoyment far out weights the few issues I have with it.

If I had to point my finger at something it would be that they could have added more campaigns (one for each nation would be nice) and more nations in general. Also, some more control and UI options would be nice. For example, the animations on hits gets old when it happens every time. It would be nice if you could toggle it to only occur when an injury is caused. I feel this would not only save time, but also add more tension when it actually does occur. That said, from the feedback they are receiving I wouldn't be surprised if that happens sooner than later.

TL:DR
If you got money to blow well worth it, if not wait for sale.

reviewText:
Blood Bowl 2 has issues when compared to its predecessor, in a vacuum. It has 10 teams currently (Wood elves and Lizardmen just added) rather than 25, and it has a new price tag, of course, however, I feel this sells short what Blood Bowl 2 does well.

The AI has been dramatically improved, which is not thrilling for those who play in human only leagues, but for those of us that play against the AI, this is a big deal. Gone are the days of the AI, as its first action of the turn, trying to dodge through 12 tackle zones and go for it twice as a dwarf. Instead, it seems to do its turn in priority order, from most likely to work to least likely, and it seems to avoid doing bizarre and silly things unlikely to have effect. As elves, it steps out of block zones, forcing you to blitz if you are going to hit it, just like a human would.

Assuming the new races do not cost an arm and a leg, and come out at a fair clip, I think Blood Bowl 2 is going to be a great upgrade on its ancestor.

reviewText:
This game is so messed up, I don´t even know where to start...
While the first Blood Bowl was at least made with some appreciation of the Boardgame, this version is missing any depth, detail and content.
The campaign is to introduce you into the rules and the game, a tutorial. Nothing more.
The Solo leagues are boring as hell. In BB1 you had a nice map with different places and you needed to achieve stuff to play the next tournament. Level up your players and buy them equippment. This one here? Nothing. Just a roster.

All of this could be ignored if the basic game would be at least bug free.  At this state right now, the game could still be a beta.
On top of that, its a really bad console port. Just click into the graphics options and you will see it. Not even an option to go full screen or windowed.
I will get my refund via Steam and leave this dissapointment behind.

reviewText: Blood Bowl 2 is a fantastic platform for playing a very good board game. The game in question has been around for about 20 years and has evolved over that time in response to all of the playtesting it has received -- it's a polished game. This implementation is pretty good; fewer bugs than BB1 with a nicer user interface, more star players, more focused on the board game element and with prettier graphics. No complaints here! Furthermore this game is being actively developed -- I don't just mean the DLC additional teams, the developers are tweaking the interface and responding to suggestions by the community. Always good to see!

reviewText:
Great but still incomplete.

bloodbowl two is a brutal, challenging american football strategy game set in the warhammer universe.

Expect Orcs, Humans, Elfs and more to battle it out scoring touchdowns, punching each other and occasionally sticking the boot in when the ref isn't looking.

Like the first version this has a steep learning curve and the death of players means it is not a game for everyone!

However Cyanide need to step up thier game and desperatly add -

* A non ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port UI with chat
* Better stats and dice log
* Optional Skill use for all important skills
* Better league system and league management
* More teams (Bloodbowl 1 has 22)
* Evolving players as they level up!

Even with all this I still love the game though and am rank 12 in NAF right now!

Catch me playing live at Twitch.tv/lewpac22

reviewText:
What do you get when you purchase Blood Bowl 2? Quite simply, a great muliplayer experience if, and only if, you are a good sport and not a rage quitter. Rather than a basic review, I will point out the differences between this version, and the previous installments.

First, there are less races. More are coming, but really, this is a minor problem. You won't see the Halflings, Vampires, Ogres with snotlings, or Goblins. These 4 teams in particular are mostly uncompetitive anyways. More teams are being added and there are enough to keep you busy from the start.

No single player experience worth mentioning exists. It really didn't exist in the previous version, either. Why? The AI was terrible beyond reason. You could easily win nearly 100% of your games once you knew the holes in the AI. If you check the message boards, players complained endlessly about the AI being stupid. Having a worthless single player campaign in Blood Bowl 2 follows the same trend as its predecessors.

This game is all about multiplayer. Having an easy cakewalk in the previous games will not teach you what this game is about. You have to understand that winning consistantly is difficult. Bad things can happen on every turn. You will only understand the unforgiving nature of this game by playing against real life people. The dice don't care about you. Rolling back to back failures happen just as astounding lucky plays do. The game is played by assuming you will fail the next roll.

Rage quitting isn't smart this time around. Be warned you will not gain star points for disconnecting, and your opponents will love you for it, because they will receive free points. Take your beatings when they are handed to you, and try again. At some point, your opponent will suffer from having horrible luck.

I suppose its worth mention the UI isn't the greatest. The previous versions has the same problem. No loss there, either.

Verdict? If you want to experience Blood Bowl like it should be, get this version. Keep in mind the original game was a board game that required another person, obviously. Wishing for a deep single player campaign is irrelevant. Playing Chess or Checkers against an AI is just as pointless. You learn more playing against actual people.

If you are weak, and would have your self esteem injured because you can't win every game you play, Don't play this game. If you can handle a few good beat downs, I'll see you on the pitch.

Ill admit the price is a little high, but since the devs are giving free races now the pricetag is bearable.
Furthermore if you like this genre, the game has immense replayability via the multiplayer.

Dont be discouraged by the low reviews, it is a great game!

reviewText:
This game has potential but there are a lot of missing or broken features, game breaking bugs, a poor UI both in game and out of game, no chat lobby, virtually non-existent league management, no player customization when they level up which means your stars look just like your rookies, no player statistics, just 3 Star Players available for each race instead of 6 for each race, and there are currently only 8 teams available instead of the full 23-25 races it should include and those additional races will be DLC that must be purchased if you want them.  It is really shocking how incompetent Cyanide/Focus are at adapting a board game.  Some of their balance changes like increasing the Orc Blitzer cost to 90k are also ridiculous and completely unnecessary.

Essentially this game is a vastly inferior product to Blood Bowl; Chaos Edition the previous version of the game which has 23 races and more features.  How Cyanide released BB2 with so many critical features of the game completely missing is incredible.

Check back in 6-9 months when more teams are available and see if they've added a lot of the features they should have had in game on release day.  The game will probably be on a 75% off sale by then and might be worth buying at that point.

Edited Oct 7:  Cyanide/Focus just held an AMA on Reddit and unfortunately they validated the worst fears of those who were skeptical of Cyanide/Focus.  Most of the missing features are not coming due to cost restraints or in some cases conscious design decisions and the same is true for many of the broken features.  It's absurd but they claim it's too costly to do the art work to have player appearances change as they level up but they are fine with charging over 5 euros for the DLC on each new race.  The wood elf and lizardman stars have their heads cut and pasted onto the bodies of generic players of their respective races.  It's beyond belief.

Edited 4/17/2016: Tomorrow will be 4 months after that Dec 18th announcement about the next four races and none of them are released yet and Cyanide has gone back into their shell of non-communication. Amazingly, the 5 minutes of work it'd take to correct the Orc roster still hasn't been done even though the game released over 6 months ago.

I've about given up hope and that's sad because I love what this game could be if they'd just communicate and put some work in. This game deserves better than Cyanide/Focus as its developer.
voteText: 39 of 79 people (49%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great game. Graphics look amazing and a massive leap forward over the old version which was so ugly it was basically unplayable. A lot of time and money has gone in to the look. The engine is slick and performs OK. No CTD's or bugs for me as of yet. The gameplay is where its at though - its massively addictive. Player/team progression rocks and is faithful to the board game with a few tweaks here and there to the rules.

Two things really stand out for me from these reviews. 1. Please take all the haters with a pinch of salt. They aren't wrong, this is bare bones compared to the previous version(s), but its functional, looks good and plays great. All the extra stuff bitter vets want that isn't included isn't something you are going to miss as a newcomer. 2. Don't be misled in to beleiving you will get satisfying multiplayer on public servers. You may, chances are though you won't.

As for the game itself - its amazing. It really is. I never played the board game and I regret it now. The rules are simple (even if the strategy surrounding a play is anything but!) and you can pick them up easily enough. There's a wealth of online resources to plumb. Every single game is fresh and suitably random at times to keep your riveted. I've beated guys with 3 players left standing. I've beaten teams much higher rated due to a stroke of luck with the dice etc.

Likewise you need to be prepared to get owned. Especially by bashy teams and agility teams. You need XP to get skills on your players to make them effective against elves and stuff. Don't judge the game by the first few matches you play.

Overall, this is a well balanced, stable, beautiful update to the classic boardgame of yore. Sure there's niggles with customization, ui, online play etc. There are things we wish were included at release. Its also overpriced. All things you can live with and/or shop around to get a better deal etc.

reviewText:
The turn-based structure of Blood Bown 2 turns the sports genre on its head, as fast reflexes are no longer needed to win. Instead, the player with the most strategy will always come out the victor. You will have to choose your moves carefully as one failed maneuver (which is determined by a roll of dice) will end the turn.

Every play made in Blood Bowl 2 will have a success rate attached to it like a roll of the dice. From simple maneuvers such as picking up the ball, to dodging tackles. Each position's stats will play a factor in this, so you don’t want to pass the ball to your linemen. Making smart decisions first, and saving riskier ones for later in your turn will allow players to do the most in one sitting.

The core gameplay is very complex, and you’ll have to learn the strengths of every class that’s in the game. So if you run straight into an online match you’ll be extremely confused. Thankfully, Blood Bowl 2 has an excellent campaign mode that serves as a tutorial. By introducing gameplay mechanics slowly, and adding to them in each subsequent game, Blood Bowl 2 manages to teach new players how to play a very complex game.

Blood Bowl 2 also features some hilarious commentary. Unlike most sports games that try their hardest to sound professional, Blood Bowl 2 matches are announced by an odd pairing of a vampire and an Orc that’s a former player. Both will crack witty jokes constantly during games. The commentary ends up doing a great job of keep up the humor even at the most tense of times.

All in all this is a great game if youre into turn based/strategy games.

reviewText:
Want to play with Wood elves or Lizard men? You better pirate the game then! Because they are pre-order exclusives and not available to buy as DLC.

I used to think that release day DLC was the worst business practice that drives people to piracy and kills the PC gaming industry, but now I think having exclusive pre order bonuses that's not even available as DLC is even worse. Piracy is not a criminal issue it is a service issue, is it really that hard for games companies to offer a better service than the pirate?! I would certainly don't mind throwing money at games companies if they can just get their act together.

For the record, I did buy the game on steam, but I don't want to play multiplayer if I can't play my favourite team (Wood Elves). I would recommend any potential buyers to either wait to pick up this game at the christmas sales when it will be bundled with more playable races, or to pirate it to play in local leagues.

reviewText:
Anyone that knows and follows me knows how much I love Games Workshop products, and Blood Bowl is no exception. I’ve played several seasons of Blood Bowl, not only on the tabletop, but also on Xbox and Steam PC. I was kind of surprised that Cyanide Studios, developers of the Blood Bowl and Dungeonbowl series, decided to make a sequel. Let’s explore Blood Bowl II together and see what works and what doesn’t with this latest addition.

30 Second Review

+ Borrows a few concepts from Football Manager

+ League organization is simplified

+ Nice but short single player campaign

– Cyanide Studios microtransaction currency “Cyans” is included

– Blood Bowl players now age and will retire on their own.

reviewText: I'm a huge Blood Bowl fan and Blood Bowl 2 hit the mark for me. Blood Bowl 2 has made some serious improvements. The game has great and extremely hard hitting animations. Mixed with the sound design when a character moves down the feild you can hear their weight stomping down the field.
